cobol:
HELLO
       IDENTIFICATION DIVISION.
       PROGRAM-ID. ADDITION.
       DATA DIVISION.
       WORKING-STORAGE SECTION.
       77 NUM_1 PIC Z(10).
       01 WS-STR PIC X(20) VALUE ' '. 
       01 WS-SPACE PIC X(20).                       
       01 WS-FIELD PIC X(20).                       

       PROCEDURE DIVISION.
       PARA.
       ACCEPT NUM_1.
       MOVE NUM_1 TO WS-STR.
       UNSTRING WS-STR DELIMITED BY ALL SPACES INTO   
                WS-SPACE,WS-FIELD.   
       DISPLAY WS-FIELD.
       ACCEPT NUM_1.
       MOVE NUM_1 TO WS-STR.
       UNSTRING WS-STR DELIMITED BY ALL SPACES INTO   
                WS-SPACE,WS-FIELD.   
       DISPLAY WS-FIELD.
       ACCEPT NUM_1.
       MOVE NUM_1 TO WS-STR.
       UNSTRING WS-STR DELIMITED BY ALL SPACES INTO   
                WS-SPACE,WS-FIELD.   
       DISPLAY WS-FIELD.
       STOP RUN.
erlang:
-module(prog).
-export([start/0]).
start() ->
    hello(3).

%% Do nothing when there is no hello to write
hello(N) when N =< 0 -> ok;
%% Else, write a 'Hello World!', and then write (n-1) hellos
hello(N) ->
   Line = io:get_line(""),
   io:format(Line),
   hello(N - 1).
fortran:
Program Hello
character(len=23) :: str
do n = 1, 3
    read *, i
    write(str,'(1i10)') i
    write(*,'(a)') trim(adjustl(trim(str)))
end do
End Program Hello
fsharp:
open System
[<EntryPoint>]
let main args =
    printfn "%s" (Console.ReadLine())
    printfn "%s" (Console.ReadLine())
    printfn "%s" (Console.ReadLine())
    0 // return an integer exit code
julia:
for i in "123"
   print(readline())

end
postscript:
% read "thinking in postscript"
% https://w3-o.cs.hm.edu/users/ruckert/public_html/compiler/ThinkingInPostScript.pdf
(%stdout) (w) file dup           % write to stdout and duplicate the file desc.
/myinput (%stdin)  (r) file def  % define myinput as stdin 
1 1 3 {                                % start, increment, end of for loop
    pop                                % pop loop index
    myinput (abcdefghij) readline pop  % read one line from std in
    writestring                        % write it to stdout - after that stack is stdout
    dup (\n) writestring               % write to stdout
    dup                                % keep stdout
} for
prolog:
main:- 
    % read and output a string
    read_line_to_string(user_input,A),writeln(A),
    read_line_to_string(user_input,B),writeln(B),
    read_line_to_string(user_input,C),writeln(C).
